title: 1. What is IPWT? A New Synthesis
introduction_html: Integrated Predictive Workspace Theory (IPWT) is a unified framework for consciousness science. It elegantly fuses three of the most powerful existing theories into a single, coherent model.
content_html:
• ➤
    Predictive Coding (The Engine): The brain is a prediction machine, constantly guessing what will happen next.
  • ➤
    Workspace Theory (The Stage): A 'global stage' where important information is selected and broadcast, becoming conscious.
  • ➤
    Integrated Information Theory (The 'Magic'): Contributes the core idea that consciousness *is* integrated information (Synergy), but reconstructed to be computationally feasible.

IPWT aims to explain how consciousness emerges, what its function is, and how it can be measured.

title: 2. The Engine: A Predictive Brain
introduction_html: The core idea of Predictive Coding is simple: your brain doesn't passively receive information. Instead, it actively predicts it.
content_html:
An Everyday Example: Catching a Ball

  1. Prediction: Your brain generates a model of the ball's trajectory.
  2. Sensory Input: Your eyes provide the actual data of the ball's position.
  3. Prediction Error: The brain compares its prediction to the actual data. The difference is the 'prediction error'.
  4. Update & Action: This error signal forces the internal model to update and triggers an action—moving your hand.

What we perceive isn't the raw sensory data, but the brain's best hypothesis that explains away the prediction error.

Perception is not a window onto reality, but a controlled hallucination.

title: 3. The Stage: A Workspace for Information
introduction_html: While the brain processes vast amounts of information unconsciously, our conscious experience is limited. Workspace Theory explains this using the metaphor of a theater.
content_html:
• Unconscious Specialists: The 'audience' consists of numerous specialized, unconscious brain modules.
  • The 'Spotlight' of Attention: A selection mechanism chooses the most relevant information to put 'on stage'.
  • Global Broadcast: Once on stage, this information is 'globally broadcast' back to the entire audience. This availability *is* what makes it conscious.

IPWT calls this stage a Workspace Instance (WSI), a flexible, dynamic network configuration.

Consciousness is the system's way of making information globally available to itself.

title: 4. The 'Magic': Integration & Synergy (Ω)
introduction_html: Conscious experience is unified. You don't experience separate events; you experience a single, coherent scene. This is integration.
content_html:
Logical Irreducibility

The integrated whole contains more information than the sum of its parts. This 'extra' information is called Synergy (Ω).

Consider 'C', 'A', 'T'. Individually, they are just shapes. When integrated, they form the concept of a 'CAT', which has emergent properties (furry, meows) that cannot be found in the individual letters.

IPWT proposes that consciousness is this synergistic, logically irreducible information. This makes it a property of information processing, which can be measured.

The whole is truly greater than the sum of its parts, and consciousness lives in that difference.

title: 5. Measuring the Immeasurable?
introduction_html: A scientific theory must be testable. If consciousness is synergistic information (Ω), how can we measure it? Direct calculation is impossibly complex.
content_html:
IPWT's solution is to use a clever proxy: Predictive Integrity (PI). The logic is as follows:

  • A system that is highly integrated (high Ω) must be very efficient.
  • An efficient system will be extremely good at making predictions.
  • Therefore, a system's predictive performance is a strong indicator of its internal information integration.

Predictive Integrity (PI)

PI is a score that quantifies how well a system is doing at minimizing its prediction errors over time.

A high PI score indicates a state of clear, stable, and effective consciousness. A low PI score indicates a disrupted or less conscious state.

By measuring PI, we can have an objective, computable handle on the level of consciousness.

title: 6. The Nature of Experience (Qualia)
introduction_html: Why does 'red' feel like red? This is the famous 'hard problem'. IPWT offers a pragmatic, functional answer, reframing the question from 'what it is' to 'what it does'.
content_html:
Qualia as Functional Labels

Subjective experiences (qualia) are not useless add-ons. They are highly efficient, compressed labels that tag internal states with immense behavioral significance.

The 'painfulness' of pain is an urgent, impossible-to-ignore functional label that screams 'Action required! Protect the body!'.

This view makes qualia computationally tractable. They are an evolutionary solution for information compression and salience tagging, allowing an organism to react quickly to what matters most.

The feeling is the function.
